Special issue on ‘Interacting with desktop virtual environments: Perception and navigation’

  • Published: 19 May 2004

Special issue on ‘Interacting with desktop virtual environments: Perception and navigation’

  • Sonali S. Morar1 &
  • Robert D. Macredie1 

Virtual Reality volume 7, pages129–130(2004)Cite this article

  • 86 Accesses

  • 2 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Introduction

Increasing graphical capabilities enable the development of much more sophisticated desktop virtual environments [3]. Examples of their use include interactive games, training and modelling applications, and abstract data visualisations and representations. Desktop virtual environments are also used to support safety-critical displays, such as flight aviation displays [7], or to augment the two-dimensional video camera images in minimally invasive surgery [1, 5]. However, usability issues continue to arise, due to the properties of desktop virtual environments, where three-dimensional, interactive graphics are presented on a two-dimensional monitor. An individual’s ability to accurately perceive and interact with, and within, desktop virtual environments may be affected by their physical views of the virtual environment, their interpretation of the visual stimuli and the manner by which they manoeuvre or are guided through the desktop virtual environment [2, 4].

This special issue focuses on the factors affecting the perception of, the interaction with, and the navigation within, desktop virtual environments. Schafer and Bowman begin the series of papers, exploring the difficulties that users have with collaborating across desktop virtual environments to undertake spatial manipulations. In particular, they investigate how different frames of reference appear to support the way in which pairs of users collaborate to complete specific spatial manipulations. For instance, the egocentric frame of reference enables the user to explore and perceive the detail of the environment first-hand, whereas the exocentric frame of reference enables the user to find objects within the environments and move them across large distances. Their findings provide an understanding of how users with different views of the same desktop virtual environment collaborate to complete spatial tasks.

Sayers et al. focus on the navigational issues of desktop virtual environments and argue that individuals experience some degree of frustration when using navigational tools to perform even relatively simple tasks. Their study examines the effectiveness of presenting a range of navigational tools such as you-are-here (YAH) maps, teleporting and undo functions. Although their results do not strongly distinguish between the effectiveness of the individual navigational tools, they found that the provision of a range of navigational tools, rather than just one tool, improves navigational performance within a desktop virtual environment and improves overall usability with the environment.

In the third paper, Steiner and Voruganti consider issues arising where the virtual environment designer has to ensure that the theme of the desktop virtual environment application (such as in a game) is relayed effectively without compromising the user’s sense of presence and control. They focus on the interpretation and motivation of visual cues, including agents, signs, landmarks and trails, on guiding users’ actions in a desktop virtual environment. Their findings indicate that, certain visual cues, such as trails, agents and signs, are more explicit in their motivation to guide users towards a specific target, whereas others, such as a fire or a tower, are less obvious. Therefore, they suggest that designers can use specific cues as either subtle or obvious forms of navigational guidance, such as architectural and environmental landmarks for the former, and trails, agents and signs for the latter.

Hicks et al., in the final paper of this issue, compare the roles of 3D representations in audio and audio-visual collaborations. In particular, the study examines how effectively specific 3-D representations presented telephone usage information in scenarios where users either: (i) communicate with their collaborator and view each other and both representations (audio visual); or (ii) only communicate verbally with each other without being able to see their collaborators’ representations (audio only). Their results provide an insight into the effectiveness of certain representational and data attributes, and contribute towards understanding the strategies, assumptions and problems that users experience during collaborative problem-solving with desktop virtual environments.

Collectively, the papers address key interaction issues, with a focus on how users perceive and navigate through 3-D environments that are presented on a 2-D monitor. Desktop virtual environments are unique in their ability to present dimensionality and endeavour to provide users with a sense of presence and immersion, affordably and conveniently [6]. The growing sophistication of these environments motivates the ongoing research efforts reported in this special issue, providing pertinent design and usability guidelines specific to the characteristics of desktop virtual environments.
